title: Synthetic Recap
body:
HOUSTON (AP) – In the quiet moments before the final shot, with the score tied and the fate of a heart-stopping game resting on his shoulders, Clyde Drexler was the picture of calm. For 47 minutes, he had carried the Houston Rockets on his back, and he was not about to let go now.

Drexler authored a historic, career-defining masterpiece Sunday night, pouring in a game-high 41 points to will the Rockets to a grueling 90-88 victory over the Indiana Pacers. In a defensive slugfest where no other Rocket could crack 14 points, "The Glide" was a singular, unstoppable force.

From the opening tip, it was clear this was Drexler’s night. He slashed to the rim, hit from deep, and lived at the free-throw line, single-handedly keeping Houston afloat against a relentless Pacers squad. Indiana, led by Reggie Miller’s 21 points, traded blows with the hosts all night, but they had no answer for Drexler’s offensive onslaught.

The game came down to a final, breathless possession. With the clock winding under 10 seconds and the score knotted at 88, the entire Summit knew where the ball was going. Drexler, isolating at the top of the key, drove left, created a sliver of space, and rose for the game-winner. The ball kissed off the glass and through the net as the buzzer sounded, sending the home crowd into a frenzy.

It was a fitting end to a legendary performance. On a night when offensive rhythm was a rare commodity, Clyde Drexler didn’t just find a rhythm; he composed a symphony, scoring nearly half his team’s points and cementing his place in the annals of clutch performances.
